supporting_quotes: Dr. Sadik joined UNFPA, the U.N.’s lead agency for advancing sexual and reproductive health and rights and improving access to contraception, as a technical advisor in 1971
events.notes: Clear role and organization linkage with specific start date.

quotes: Dr. Sadik joined UNFPA, the U.N.’s lead agency for advancing sexual and reproductive health and rights and improving access to contraception, as a technical advisor in 1971

Dr. Sadik joined UNFPA, the U.N.’s lead agency for advancing sexual and reproductive health and rights and improving access to contraception, as a technical advisor in 1971 and quickly rose to become chief of its program division in 1973.
From 1982 to 1987, she served as assistant executive director.
U.N. Secretary-General Javier Pérez de Cuéllar appointed Dr. Sadik as UNFPA’s executive director in 1987

Dr. Nafis Sadik addresses an event on Capitol Hill in 1990 as leading House Republican family planning champions Representatives Bill Green of New York (former PAI board member) and John Edward Porter of Illinois look on.
From UNFPA’s founding in 1969, the United States had been UNFPA’s largest bilateral donor until concerns about UNFPA’s assistance to China

From UNFPA’s founding in 1969, the United States had been UNFPA’s largest bilateral donor until concerns about UNFPA’s assistance to China — where reports of human rights abuses resulting from the government’s zealous implementation of its infamous “one-child” policy — began to surface in the early 1980s
leading to the withdrawal of the entire U.S. contribution of $36 million in 1985.
Over the following 10 years, Dr. Sadik led the development of the fundraising strategy that resulted in a doubling of contributions from other bilateral donors.
Over Dr. Sadik’s 13-year tenure, UNFPA grew to a staff

Nafis Sadik was born on 18 August 1929 in Jaunpur, British India
Nafis Sadik (18 August 1929 – 14 August 2022)
She returned to Pakistan in 1954 with her husband, to become a civilian doctor in army hospitals.
She worked until 1963 in women's and children's wards in Pakistan Armed Forces hospitals.
In 1964, Sadik was appointed head of the Health Section of the Government’s Planning Commission.
Sadik joined the Pakistan Central Family Planning Council in 1966 as Director of Planning and Training
She was appointed Deputy Director-General in 1968
and Director-General in 1970.

(Population Today, November/December 2000) Many people think of Nafis Sadik as the symbol of the remarkable new consensus that emerged from the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) in Cairo in 1994.
Many people think of Nafis Sadik as the symbol of the remarkable new consensus that emerged from the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) in Cairo in 1994.
As a young doctor in Pakistan in the late 1950s, she taught rural women and men about family planning.
I have known Nafis since 1975.

When I headed the U.S. Agency for International Development’s Office of Population in the early 1980s, she and I worked to minimize disruptions caused by the Reagan administration’s efforts to eliminate U.S. population assistance.
In 1992, Nafis was named secretary-general of the ICPD.

supporting_quotes: was elected as 1988 Fellow ad eundem of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in the United Kingdom
events.notes: Fellow ad eundem is an honorary title.

quotes: She was appointed Deputy Director-General in 1968
and Director-General in 1970
Dr Sadik joined UNFPA in October 1971
and became Chief of the Programme Division in 1973
From 1977 until April 1987, she was Assistant Executive Director
Dr Sadik joined IUSSP in 1968 as a member
and was an active member of the IUSSP Council from 1977 to 1981
She was the first female recipient of the Hugh Moore Award in 1976
and was elected as 1988 Fellow ad eundem of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists
In May 1989, Dr Sadik received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from the Johns Hopkins university
and in May 1993, from the Brown university
During its annual meeting in Washington DC, in February 1994, she received the International Award 1993
In April 1994, Dr Sadik was elected President of the International Society for development (ISD)
for the period 1994-1997
